column4: I need of help, I cant get connected to the internet (neither wired nor wireless).....
rather.
Mind, I am getting a signal, its just that when trying to load any page it times out
Yes

control-c
Getting replies

warning message parser reports malformed message packet
timed out
one sec
Ok
type: cat /etc/resolv.conf and paste the contents to pastebin.ca for me
not on the pc with linux but it just says do not edit, then nameserver 192.168.1.1
what kind of router is it? seems like its sending bad dns replies to you
Good question
you could override resolv.conf with some dns servers that are known to work. (and tell dhcpclient NOT to overwrite it next lease!)
Ok, sounds good
http://linux.derkeiler.com/Newsgroups/comp.os.linux.networking/2005-09/0088.html seems to be the same issue as you.
So just use this as a guide then?
its just an interesting thing i found in google. not sure the cause.
Ok
how do i override resolv.conf?
look in /etc/dhcp3/dhclient.conf

you need to tell dhcpd not to overwrite your changes. then just edit the file with your fav text editor under sudo, and change 192.168.1.1 to another nameserver that works. 128.193.4.20 is oregonstate's nameserver for example.
alternately, you can use the gui.. under the network settings dialog, theres a DNS tab. delet ethe 192.168.1.1 and add osu's there.
how do i tell it not to override?
i dont remember the exact syntax, but in the man page for dhclient.conf it has them. you want to 'supersede' domain-name and domain-name-servers
it says supersede domain-name fugue.com home.vix.com
No
OH. yeah the # in front means 'comment'
I just reinstalled 7.10 tonight
thats just an example
Ok
so just like that only take out the # in front and change it.. :)
The whole file is an example...
says its a sample config file
yeah. uncomment the 2 lines and change the host to yours and the 127.0.0.1 to the dns server you want to use
says i dont have the permission to save the file
you need to use sudo to edit it. its a root owned file
in a terminal, run sudo gedit /etc/dhcp3/dhclient.conf
And change hostname to what?
anything you want really.
Oh really now? :D
its just for advanced cases
yeah.. or even unplug and replug should do it.
I'm going to connect wirelessly
give it a try ;)
No Go
cat the resolv.conf again and make sure your changes stayed
so it overwrote it again.
go ahead and reboot to make sure dhcpclient is reading your changed config file. then edit the resolv.conf again and then try it...
Hold on a sec
now its not even timing out
it keeps changing the second nameserver to the old one
but its still timing out
supersede line is still a comment with the fugue.com etcetera
your talking about /etc/dhcp3/dhclient.conf ?
yes
could you just throw both files on pastebin.ca so i can check what you did?
both files? isnt it only one?

dhcpclient overwrites resolv.conf. so 1st your telling it to do so differently, and then your checking that its done it right. resolv.conf is what the system uses to do DNS resolution (turn names into ip addresses)
so you need to make the proper lines in dhclient.conf first.. then look at resolv.conf to see that its correct.
I can get you one... the dhclient.conf. resolv.conf is disappearing when i put it on the flash drive (not using the pc with the problem so...)
http://pastebin.ca/859573
let ya see the foolishness i did...
that looks correct
now what does resolv.conf say exactly?
hrm. i wonder whats going on then
try this: host google.com 208.67.222.222
timed out
ahh. so the router is also BLOCKING dns requests, in additon to serving bad ones.
can you get a better one? or figure out somehow whats wrong with it? what kind is it?
shouldnt be deffective as im using it to come here
could be it works but is doing something odd linux doesnt like
paste the error it gives you again about bad request? i lost it
Warning: Message parser reports malformed message packet

Warning recursion requested but not available
some other randomness

nah
this could be an ipv6 related bug. hmm

k
googling for this is coming up with a lot of results but no answers. it could be a bug in pdnsd maybe used on the router?  Since its blocking regular requests, its kinda got you in a hard spot :/
